node.text:
Check this reel out for some torticollis tips! 

Reminder, if you think your child has torticollis, please be sure to mention it to their pediatrician. These activities can be performed to both sides, whether a torticollis present or not, and are great ways to encourage a neutral head position & equal strength on both sides of the neck. See previous posts & TORTICOLLIS highlight for more!

Activities: 
+gently kiss your little one to encourage a stretch to the opposite side. 

+position all toys on the non-preferred side. Encourage them to turn just their head and engage with toys. Tip- gently anchor their chest like shown to ensure the rotation is coming only from their head, not their whole trunk. Let them actively turn to the toys- don’t force their head over! 

+rotate what side of the crib their head is on. Babies will naturally turn towards the door, so rotating their head position will encourage turning in both directions.

+see previous post for football carry 

+encourage righting reactions and neck strengthening/stretching by gently tilting side to side (best for 4-5+ months when righting reactions begin to emerge for many babes). With torticollis- you’ll see that one side has much less of a reaction when tipped. We want to see the reactions be equal, so pulling in the gentle kissing or football carry can be a great idea if you’re noticing differences! 

Hope that helps- drop your questions below & tag a parent that could use this info!

node.text:
The football carry! 

First- as with everything I share, if you think your child may have torticollis or you have any specific concerns about their development, please be sure to bring those concerns to your pediatrician. This is not individualized medical advice and should not replace assessment by your medical team. See START HERE highlight for more specifics! 

One of the reasons I love this carry so much is that not only is it fantastic for gently stretching the neck muscles (specifically the ones we want to elongate when torticollis is present), but it also brings in a nice change to the vestibular input your little one receives, and can also help alleviate belly discomfort if that’s a struggle! 

There is also no harm in carrying this way from day one, whether torticollis is present or not, as long as you’re fully supporting them and ensuring they’re secure in your arms! 

So, how do you do it? The big thing to understand with torticollis is as mentioned in the last two posts, there is a usually two components. A tilt to the SAME side as the tight muscle and a rotation to the OPPOSITE. Addressing those components separately is key! 

To do the football carry, have your baby’s cheek against your for arm. Their arm should not be resting above your for arm, or it will negate the stretch! Having their check rest against your forearm will create space between their ear and shoulder, and elongate the muscles that would be tight with torticollis. This carry should be comfortable, tears or fussing shouldn’t be present! If they’re not loving it, try carrying them more vertically, and easing into sidelying as they settle. 

More detailed overview is in my TORTICOLLIS highlight, specifically in regards to figuring out which cheek should test against your forearm. If there is a right tilt, right cheek should be against right forearm. Switch for a left tilt. 

Hope this helps! Stay tuned for more tips over the next few days on gently addressing the tilt and rotation characteristic of torticollis. Drop your questions below and tag a parent that could use this info!

node.text:
Let’s talk torticollis & asymmetry! 

This video is a really quick example of what *can* happen with torticollis in regards to development of asymmetries in motor milestones. 

Now - this is not always the case!!! There are times that torticollis is truly just a musculoskeletal issue that needs to be addressed, and it will resolve without the development of asymmetries or delays in milestones. 

BUT, there are also times that asymmetries being present are one of the first things noted - things like parents seeing their child only looking in one direction, strongly preferring to use one hand, or roll in one direction, etc. These asymmetries can and often do impact the development of motor milestones, and absolutely need to be addressed in order to prevent further difficulty.

In this video- you can imagine that if a baby is in the characteristic position of torticollis (head tilted in one direction and rotated to the opposite- see previous post if you’re not sure what I mean), that can lead to them looking only in one direction, seeing one hand much more than the other - which can lead to reaching more with that hand. If they are reaching and grabbing one foot more than the other, that can lead to happy baby to one side, ultimate rolling to one side from back to belly, and if on their belly the entire weight of their head is shifted off center, we can often see rolling from belly to back in only one direction as well! 

So, what do you do if you’re noticing asymmetries or the classic torticollis presentation? 

First, definitely speak to your pediatrician and discuss whether a PT evaluation is warranted! It is often ideal to have it assessed if torticollis is suspected - that’ll  help determine the best course of treatment (whether its at home stretches and positioning or actual skilled PT interventions) and help guide you to the best care for your little one!

Second, stay tuned…I’ll be sharing lots of tips and tricks in posts on environment set up to encourage equal movement, gentle carrying techniques, and lots more! 

Drop your questions regarding torticollis & asymmetries below, and check out my TORTICOLLIS highlight for more in depth information.

node.text:
Let’s talk torticollis!⠀
⠀
Torticollis refers to restriction in the sternocleidomastoid muscle (SCM) in the neck. Although it often involves more than just this muscle- by definition, that’s the trouble spot!⠀
If you put your hand on the RIGHT side of your neck, bring your RIGHT ear closer to your RIGHT shoulder, & then turn your head toward the LEFT, you will feel that muscle bulge. If you were sort of “stuck” in this position, that would be considered a RIGHT torticollis. ⠀
⠀
So, the PRIMARY (but not only) muscle responsible for torticollis causes a tilt in the SAME direction as the tight muscle & a rotation in the OPPOSITE.⠀
⠀
Nice & confusing, amiright? 🤪🥴⠀
⠀
So, torticollis can occur in utero (often the case) or after birth, especially in the first 3-4 months of life when little ones are reliant on us for positioning - meaning where we place them, they stay. ⠀
⠀
Often times, the first signs of torticollis are a parent saying “my child loves to look one way”, or “my child always wants to turn to the....”, or noticing that your child’s head is always tilted to one side in pictures, etc. ⠀
⠀
More significant signs can include asymmetries in the face, flattening of the back of the skull on one side, neck & trunk tightness, limited range of motion or ability to track in one direction, only bringing one hand to their mouth, only rolling in one direction, or even curving of their trunk toward one side. Again, in general, It is often very subtle at first!⠀
⠀
Now … here’s the thing, please don’t panic. I want to share this information with you because torticollis is common, often goes unnoticed until it’s worse, and can impact many milestones, BUT in many cases, it can be managed with conservative treatment & the earlier the better for beginning treatment! My hope with this info is to empower you and provide the tools to notice something may be up, and trust your instinct to bring those concerns to your ped to discuss if further evaluation is warranted. ⠀
⠀
So, as this series progresses, I’ll be sharing lots more info & tips, but for now, drop any torticollis questions you want covered below, and tag a parent that could use this info!

*alt-text in comment

node.text:
Shared this in stories yesterday but based on feedback, figured it needs a spot on the grid! 

If your little one loves to play with stickers, but needs your help to get them off, try this!

Try peeling the back of the sticker page off, and then letting them try. When the back page is on, there is nothing for their nail to grab easily that allows them to be successful. Think - we often have to bend the page a little to get the edge up, even as adults! Removing the back of the sticker page often lets their nail catch a tiny bit, and they can peel it off from there. 

Disclaimer - we are always direct supervision when using stickers, and we didn’t introduce them until my oldest was around 3. If they’re not ready for stickers, if they are mouthing things, etc - use your discretion!! You know your babies best - this is just a tip for when you get to that stage ❤️

And a major shoutout to all the OT’s I’ve worked with over the years that shared this tip with me - y’all are the real MVP’s! 

So tell me- have you tried this hack, and did it work for you?!

*alt text pinned in comments!

node.text:
Bow legs, aka genuvarum, is when knees are further away from each other when ankles are touching.⠀
⠀
The appearance of legs being bowed is generally normal in babies up until about 2 years of age. Some sources say 3, but most orthopedists I’ve worked with would rather see a child closer to 2 if it’s not resolving or improving. Other times it would be a concern would be if it’s one sided, or if it’s impacting function (ie: tripping & falling, appearing to walk on the outsides of the feet, any appearance of pain). ⠀
⠀
Bow leg appearance is thought to be from in utero positioning, when the legs are bent up while in the womb. As a child moves around during crawling, pull to stand, cruising, & eventually walking, the forces of gravity combined with weight bearing causes bones to change & mature - which improves alignment & ultimately moves from the bow leg appearance to legs looking straight. ⠀
⠀
An anecdotal piece of info - the earlier a child walks, the more bow legged they often appear. One theory I’ve seen is that this is because they are closer to that in utero positioning & haven’t had quite as much weight bearing yet, BUT regardless, it should improve as they walk! ⠀
⠀
For reference - check out the videos attached. 

+in the first video, she is a very new walker. Legs are really far apart & steps are more side to side than forward. 

+In the next, legs are coming closer together, but see how that also makes it look a little more bowed (remember - as feet come closer together, the leg alignment is still working it’s way towards straight, so the bowing appearance is more noticeable.). 

+In the next, you can see after about 4 months of walking, even though this video isn’t a straight shot of her walking, her legs are straighter. 

+In the last video, she’s been walking for around a year, and they’re completely straight 👍
⠀
So - the takeaway is, bowed appearance of the legs can be completely normal! Keep an eye on it, & you should see improvements as your little one practices being uprights against gravity. Again, as always, if you have *ANY* concerns, talk to your ped and/or request a further assessment, but hopefully this helps to set your mind at ease!

node.text:
Suction cup toys- standing > steps edition!

Here’s the thing- height placement is everything for this one, and one HUGE thing to consider is that when you’re doing these activities on a vertical surface, which provides VERY little stability (as compared to along a couch or something they can grip with their hands). That means that this is basically the last step towards letting go with one or both hands and balancing- so exciting! 

So here’s some motor play ideas for this stage…. 

+tall kneeling (place toys at eye level when on their knees)

+pull to stand with minimal hand support (place toys at eye level in kneel AND a little higher to encourage the transition!) 

+cruising along a vertical surface (place toys in a line one to two steps apart to encourage the weight shift and sideways stepping attempts) 

+transitions in/out of stand with less hand support & squatting practice (place toys at eye level when in standing, and then at various lower points to encourage squatting)

Hope this helps! Drop your questions below & tag a parent that could use some fun play ideas! 

*affil links to a bunch of different suction cup toy options is saved in my SQUIGZ highlight 🤍

*alt text pinned in comments!

node.text:
Suction cup toys- crawling edition! 

Crawling takes a TON of strength and coordination through the shoulders, hips, and core muscles- so activities that work those areas either alone or all together are so powerful for working towards that true hands and knees crawl we love to see! 

With suction cup toys- here are some ideas for placement.

Placing the toys ABOVE eye level encourages them to get their head up, weight bear through extended arms, and weight shift to lift one hand and play (the exact motion we need to crawl on hands and knees). 

Placing them even a little higher than that can encourage playing in tall kneeling, an awesome activity for hip strengthening, and one that really quickly often leads into pulling to stand, as seen in the third video! 

Stay tuned for tomorrow’s reel on standing activities with suction cup toys- and tag a parent that could use some simple motor based play ideas like this!

*alt text pinned in comments!

node.text:
So, what can you use suction cup toys for with floor skills? Check it out! 👇

First video- these can also be done on a therapy ball- look at that beautiful weight shifting to just one arm & reaching with the other with her head up. Those are things required for so many floor skills, including pushing up on forearms/hands, lifting your head off the floor during time, and rolling! It’s also precursors to activities like crawling, which requires extended arms & head up 🙌

Second video- rolling practice! Place suction cup toys above eye sight and slightly off on a diagonal. This helps use vision & heating to drive head position & help that roll happen! 
 
You can also use them in this position to encourage side lying & bringing hands towards midline (Lay them side ways facing the mirror) & to prolong tummy time (third video!)

Stay tuned for crawling & standing suction cup editions, and drop your questions below! 

*where to purchase these is saved in my LINKS highlight as well!

*alt text pinned in comments!

node.text:
Squigz - some of my favorite suction cup toys - SITTING edition! 

Any suction cup toy absolutely works, but squibs (especially the whirly set ones shown in the beginning here) are absolute favorites for me, and over the next couple days I’ll be sharing some reels on how to use them for motor/purposeful play in a variety of positions. 

So, here goes SITTING! 

+Having them off to the side in sitting encourages SO many great things - weight shifting, which is the beginning of development of protective reactions in sitting (your little one getting their hand out to catch themselves from a fall). What’s really cool is that protective reactions to the side actually also lead into transitions in/out of sit, and development of the hands & knees position for crawling. So awesome! 

+Fine motor development in sitting - this is another thing that majorly contributes to balance & stability in sitting, and ultimately the ability to get in/out of sit on their own. You can obviously do this with any toy - grab a bucket or bowl and work on in/out concepts too! 

+Transitions in/out of sit - again, another one that can work with any toy, but was a great example here of how these aren’t JUST suction cup toys! Placement in varying spots, especially to the sides, encourages that trunk rotation needed, getting arms down to the side, weight shifting in sitting - so many good things! 

+Distraction at a restaurant without having to worry about it falling to the floor….need I say more?! 

Common Sitting struggle problem solving: For both of these - if you don’t have suction cup toys, you can also use colored paper taped up, magnets, tissue paper taped, etc!

+If your child tends to flop forward when in sitting, try placing squigs ABOVE chest height as pictured here, which encourages extension of the trunk by using vision! 

+If you child tends to push backwards when in sitting, try placing squigz BELOW chest height as pictured last, which encourages flexion of the trunk by using vision! 

Hope that helps -stay tuned for more SQUIGZ ideas in a variety of positions!
